title: docs/generators.md description of RangeGenerator incomplete and/or misleading
body:
`docs/generators.md` says of the `RangeGenerator`:

>  RangeGenerator<T> -- generates all values inside an arithmetic range

This is misleading and could lead user to incomplete tests.  The range generated is actually open at the end - `[n .. m)` - that is, _not_ inclusive of the last value.  Although similar to the usual "for loop" it is not (IMO) what is expected: If the user writes `range('A','Z')` he is most probably thinking that _all_ values from `'A'` to `'Z'` _inclusive of both `'A'` and `'Z'`_ will be generated - that is, 26 tests.  The user would be surprised (well, ok, _I_ was surprised) to discover that `'Z'` wasn't generated and if he _didn't_ discover it - IMO, likely? - then he wouldn't be getting the test coverage he desired.

The page could document that clearly in text and/or via an example.

(Actually, "inside an arithmetic range" is imprecise enough you might actually think it meant the interval open at _both_ ends ... but that would be ridiculous ...)

(Note that in a regular expression the notation `[A-Z]` denotes the closed interval including both `'A'` and `'Z'`. Yes, to use that as a justification would be invoking the logical fallacy of _argumentum ad iusto expressio_ - arguing by regular expression - a grievous mistake made by many programmers.  Plus they explicitly chose square bracket notation meaning closed end intervals. Nevertheless, it is a familiar use of a "range notation" that includes _both_ ends.)

(I'm not suggesting that, at this late date, the semantics of `RangeGenerator` be changed, just that it be clearly documented.)
